title.rendered: The Dark Side of the Internet

content.rendered:
The Internet is a very common word in 21 century. In today most of the peoples are using the internet to do their work easily and to get entertainment. We can agree the Internet is a very useful source but do you know the internet has a dark side?

I will not go to discuss bad things on the internet and Enter websites with inappropriate content for children, time-wasting with social media and chat with fake peoples and share personal information, Play without time limits on the internet, These things.

do you know the internet has a bad side over the above mentioned things.

In today article I am going to tell about these things

These are called Dark webs and Deep webs.

We are searching for something using Google, yahoo, or any kind of web browser. We are called that a surface web. But a marvelous thing is they view us as 4% of the information. Another 96% of information is in deep webs and dark webs.

Dark webs and deep webs are the same?

No , the deep web and the dark web are not the same things, though they can overlap significantly.

Then what are the deep webs?

The Deep Web includes web pages that are not accessible via search engines. These include online enterprise systems like corporate intranet pages, online banking sites, web-based email pages, and paywalls, among many others.

What can people do using deep webs?

The deep web holds the content that’s invisible to search engines. Here are a few examples of what’s on the deep web:

  • The content of your personal email accounts
  • The content of your social media accounts
  • The content of your online banking accounts
  • Data that companies store on their private databases
  • Content contained within scientific and academic databases
  • Medical records
  • Legal documents

A lot of what exists on the deep web consists of information that you probably wouldn’t want to turn up in a web search, like your checking account information because it’s private and could be misused.

you think about that;

If you have to log in to one of your accounts by providing a user name, password, or some other type of authentication, the information you access is on the deep web.

That’s a good thing. The deep web can help protect your personal information and privacy.

What are the Dark webs?

The dark web is a layer even deeper technically also part of the deep web but focused on illegal activities and services. It can be pretty gruesome. Some people call it the place where the darkest side of humanity surfaces.

Then what is the secret and what it has??

  • Various drugs for the Marketplace, from mild recreational and borderline legal ones to hard stuff.
  • Various firearms and ammunition for the Marketplace, most likely unregistered
  • The few rare books
  • 3D printing stuff for lots of blueprints, from legal stuff to illegal things
  • A so-called Hidden wiki portal, claiming to be the original Wikipedia number plus its mirrors
  • Children pornography content, animals, war prisoners, 
  • How to cook human meat and video footage on recipes

Is It Illegal to Access the Deep Web or the Dark Web?

In short, no, it is not illegal to go browsing on a non-indexed page. Or to use a high-privacy like Tor, traditionally associated with browsing the deep web and dark web.

What is illegal is not just to access and browse the overlay networks called the deep web or dark web, but to look into illegal services sold on these networks. Or to attempt to hack things without permission. That’s what can get someone in trouble, not just simply the browsing.

However, you should note that accessing the dark web without plenty of cyber security precautions can be dangerous for peoples.

title.rendered: Lesson 01 : Am / Is / Are (Present Tense — Be Verb)

content.rendered:
‘Be’ verb is used when a sentence doesn`t have a main verb. In that situation, it is a linking verb. It doesn’t describe an action. It tells us more about the subject of the sentence.

We use am / is / are as,

• The main verb

• A helping verb

Example: — I am a doctor. ( Here, ‘am’ is the main verb)

Example:- I am eating rice. (Here, ‘am’ is a helping verb)

What is the Main Verb?

The main verb is a verb that can stand alone in a sentence.

I eat rice ( eat is the main verb)

we can`t say that as “I am eat rice”. This is wrong. As there is one main verb eat we don`t need another verb because the main verb can stand alone.

I happy — Wrong

I am happy — Correct

Here am is the main verb as there is no other verb.

Affirmative Form / Positive form

I + am

Singular subject + is

Plural subject + are

Examples:-

• I am kind. / I`m kind.

• He is a farmer. / He`s a farmer.

• She is a teacher. / She`s a teacher.

• It is a book. / It`s a book.

• You are good. / You`re good.

• We are children. / We`re children.

• They are birds. / They`re birds.

• My father is a driver.

• Kasun and Kamal are tall.

Negative form

I + am + not

Singular subject + is + not

Plural subject + are + not

Examples:-

• I am not kind. / I`m not kind.

• He is not a farmer. / He isn`t a farmer.

• She is not a teacher. / She isn`t a teacher.

• It is not a book. / It isn`t a book.

• You are not good. / You aren`t good.

• We are not children. / We aren`t children.

• They are not birds. / They aren`t birds.

• My father is not a driver.

• Kasun and Kamal are not all.

Interrogative form / Question form

Am + I

Is + Singular subject

Are + Plural subject

Examples:-

• Am I kind?

• Is he a farmer?

• Is she a teacher?

• Is it a book?

• Are you good?

• Are we children?

• Are they birds?

• Is my father a driver?

• Are Kasun and Kamal tall?

notice one thing here we don`t put a full stop in places where we have put a question mark.

Try out the following examples:-

The answers are,

1.am

2.are

3.is

4.is

5.is

6.are

7.are

8.are

9.is

10.is

You can take the Sinhala translation as a video from the following link : –

https://youtu.be/FA6Obc7M2Os

content.rendered:
With the quarantine period, you may stay more time with your loved ones. so, I think these idioms may help you in your relationship.

01.From the bottom of my heart

We use the above phrase,

  • With a sincere and deep feeling
  • To show sincerity towards something
  • To express truthfulness to someone
  • When saying something genuinely

Example 01:- Tell me from the bottom of your heart, Do you love me?

Example 02:-I am apologizing to you from the bottom of my heart, I won’t hurt you again.

02. Broken heart/ Break someone’s heart

We use this phrase,

  • When a person is emotionally sad
  • To specify the loss of a loved one
  • When there`s a romantic loss or break up
  • When a relationship is ended.

Example 01:- Please stop worrying. Your broken heart will heal with the passage of time.

Example 02:-I know he broke your heart, but there are other boys out there who are better than him.

03.The Other half / The Better half

  • The better half is the husband, wife, or partner of someone
  • Maybe the tour partner or spouse
  • Can also refer to a very good friend

Example 01: -I can`t enjoy the party without my other half being here.

Example 02:-I love to go to the nearest park with my better half every evening.

04.Next of Kin/ Next to Kin

We use this word phrase to describe the nearest living blood relative or relatives of a person.

If you are a married person, then we can say your spouse is your next of kin. If you are divorced or widowed, any kids are your next of kin. If you are single, then your parents. In case when parents are not alive, your siblings are your next of kin, in order by birth.

Example 01:-His next of kin have been informed and that person is supporting in the investigation.

Example 02:- I think we should call the next of kin of the injured person.

05.On the mend

We use the word phrase on the mend when there`s an improvement in health after an illness or when restored to a previous, better condition. also, we call a relationship is on the mend when it is improving.

Example 01:-Their friendship went through a tough time but it is on the mend now.

Example 02:-Their marriage was in trouble for a while but they have been working on it. It seems that it is on the mend.

06.Mr.Right /Ms.Right /Mr.Fix

  • Mr.Right or Ms.Right is the best future life partner for someone
  • It is also used to describe the person that you imagine to spending your future with
  • We can say he /she is the ideal one that you want to marry
  • Mr. Fix is someone who repairs or fixes broken down things. 🙂

Example 01:- I wish that I could meet Mr. Right soon because all of the men that I meet seem so immature.

Example 02:-I think I am in love with Sarah and she is Ms.Right for me.

Example 03:-I’ve been single for ages, I don’t know where to find my Ms.Right.

content.rendered:
Do not Say…

In your daily English life, you have to stop saying these common words and be smart by practicing alternative words that can be used instead.

Do not say Thank You

01.you are a lifesaver

If you come out of a difficult situation because of someone you can use this phrase.

Example:- hey, you are a lifesaver. If you were not with me I will not pass the exam.

02. You rock / You are the best

If someone has done something significant and unexpected you can use this phrase.

Example:- I didn`t expect this much, you`re the best.

03. What would I do without you?

When you are deeply grateful to someone

Example:- I can`t imagine what would I do without you.

04. You`re a Legend/ You`re an Angel

You can use this when you are extremely happy about something which has done by someone. it is similar to you are amazing.

Example: — Oh! you`re a Legend.

Do not say Welcome

These are some words you can use instead of saying you`re welcome.

01. No problem / No Worries.

No problem is a little American and no worries is a little British.

Example:- No worries. I`m happy to help you.

02.Anytime.

You can simply use this word when someone says ‘Thank You!’

Example:-

Raj:- Thank you for getting me off the hook.

Alen:- Anytime Raj.

03.My pleasure.

Saying this is a little bit formal so you can make it casually saying only pleasure.

Example:-

Tishara:- Thank you for rescuing me today.

Katharina:- It was my pleasure to help you.

04. Not at all.

This can be used When u want to say to someone that “you don’t have to thank me”.

Example:-

Rash -Thank you so much, Alen. I`m happy that you helped me.

Rufina:- Not at all.

Choose some words from the list and try to add them to your vocabulary. Happy Learning. 🙂

content.rendered:
NEST JS ( Part 03 )

 

In my first article on Nest.Js I have given enough introduction about Nest.Js and in my second article you have learned the installation part of the Nest.Js framework. So today we are going to learn about the building blocks of Nest.Js. Here I used term building blocks of Nest.Js to controllers, Providers and Modules which we need when building Nest.Js applications.

Controllers

First we will consider about controller in Nest.Js. The concept of Controller is nothing new to us because you might have used MVC based frameworks previously. Controllers are doing the major part of application by mapping endpoints to functionalities and they are responsible to handle incoming request and return responses to the client-side of the application. The routing mechanism is able to control which controller receive which request. As an example, if we make an API call to some endpoint let’s say ‘/todos’, the controller receives this request and returns a particular response.

We can create a controller using cli by executing $ nest g controller todos command or just creating a typescript class and annotate with @controller decorator. Then nest creates a routing map which links requests to the corresponding controllers.

The term ‘todos’ within the controller decorator will prompt the TodosController to handle any ‘/todos’ GET request within an application and return the appropriate response. Nest provides standard HTTP request endpoint decorators such as @Put(), @Patch(), @Delete(), @Options(), @All() and @Head() and also each of them represents its respective HTTP request method.

Providers

As I mentioned in my previous articles Nest.Js is heavily inspired by Angular Framework. Similar to angular providers we can use to inject dependencies in controllers and other providers. Nest classes such as services, repositories, factories and helpers can be defined as providers. Nest.Js service provider is a JavaScript class with a special decorator called @Injectable() decorator.

We can create a service provider using cli by executing $ nest g service todos command or just creating a typescript class and annotate with @Injectable() decorator.

In here provider has created a class with two methods create() and findAll().

Modules

Nest.Js is module-based just like angular and these modules are Typescript files decorated with @Module decorator. This @Module() decorator provides metadata that Nest parses to structure of the application. Each Nest.Js application should have at least one module, a root module named AppModule. AppModule is the top-level module and it is enough for a small application. It is good enough to break a large application into several modules because it helps to maintain the application code. They can contain components, service providers and pipes as well as can import functionality, exported from other modules and can export selected functionality for use by other modules. Usually in most applications there are multiple modules each included a set of functionalities.

We can create a single module using cli by executing $ nest g module todos command or just creating a typescript class and annotate with @Module decorator. As an example in TodosModule, we are exported a TodosModule that contains the TodosController and TodosService.

There are some other important concepts in Nest.Js. Let’s briefly consider those too.

DTO

A DTO is an object that defines how the data will be sent over the network. We could determine the DTO schema by using TypeScript interfaces, or by simple classes.

Interfaces

TypeScript interfaces are used for type-checking and defining the types of data that can be passed to a controller or a Nest service.

Dependency Injection

Dependency injection is a technique whereby one object supplies the dependencies of another object. A “dependency” is an object that can be used, for example a service. Instead of a client specifying which service it will use, something tells the client what service to use. The “injection” refers to the passing of a dependency (a service) into the object (a client) that would use it.

Pipes

A pipe is a class annotated with the @Injectable() decorator. Pipes implement the PipeTransform interface. You can use pipes to transform the input data into the desired output format and validate the request data (headers, body, query, query params). Nest interposes a pipe just before a method is invoked, and the pipe receives the arguments destined for the method.

That’s it for today. I hope you have got an idea about building blocks of Nest.Js. See you soon in my next article.

Happy Learning !!!

So today we are going to learn about the building blocks of Nest.Js. Here I used term building blocks of […]
